Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Novel biomass-derived chemical species hold significant promise for providing societal needs for new and improved products such as next-generation materials, polymers, corrosion inhibitors, lubricants, antimicrobials, food preservatives, insecticides, etc., with enhanced performance properties. In the search for improved products, biomass provides access to chemical species that cannot be effectively derived from petrochemical sources. Despite the desire for novel molecules, a significant challenge in their identification and development is the relative dearth of understanding between chemical species and final product performance attributes. This lack of structure-function knowledge creates a dilemma as the precise chemical target for improved product performance cannot be easily defined and as such no single target chemical species can be systematically identified.

The goal of this EAGER project is to advance the systematic identification of bioprivileged molecules, which are biology-derived chemical intermediates that can be efficiently converted to a diversity of chemical products including both novel molecules and drop-in replacements, by integrating a reaction network computational framework with experimental-driven knowledge of feasible reactions involving multifunctional molecules derived from biomass. The project will utilize the computational framework to generate candidate bioprivileged molecules, so the final objective is to assess whether these predicted molecules are potential bioprivileged molecules. If successful our approach will dramatically alter the search for useful, new biomass-derived chemicals as well as provide chemical targets for bioenegineering efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this EAGER project was to advance the systematic identification of bioprivileged molecules, which are biology-derived chemical intermediates that can be efficiently converted to a diversity of chemical products, including both novel molecules and drop-in replacements, by integrating a reaction network computational (NetGen) framework with experimental-driven knowledge of feasible reactions involving multifunctional molecules derived from biomass. The project utilized the results from NetGen to generate candidate bioprivileged molecules to inform organic chemistry-directed synthesis of derivatives from those potential bioprivileged molecules. The NetGen framework was used to generate C6 molecules that could be candidate bioprivileged molecules through funneling possible molecules to a set of 100 structures. The project team evaluated those 100 molecules and selected several for subsequent synthesis work. Particularly promising was the C6 molecule, maltol. A number of C-C coupling reactions were developed for maltol, which demonstrated its promise as a bioprivileged molecule. The second major activity was to get a list of possible C5 molecules from NetGen, which led to a synthetically demonstrated C5 bioprivileged molecule, 3-hydroxymethyl 3-buten-2-one.

While progress was made on assessing potential bioprivileged molecules, a challenge remained to screen through the enormous number of biological-derived molecules to find the best candidates. The activities of this EAGER project led the team to conceptualize a more systematic process to accomplish this objective. As this project evolved, we found a great deal of performance screening has been performed on plant-derived secondary metabolites, which has led to isolated claims of positive performance attributes for specific "identified molecules" in the literature. This knowledge led us to propose aggregating the natural product performance screening results through a data mining approach. The molecular structures identified from the literature would then be used in conjunction with the NetGen computational platform to identify key bioprivileged molecules that could be used to synthesize the literature-identified molecular structures. These bioprivileged molecules could be leveraged for the synthesis of the "identified structure" but also to provide the basis for generating a library of compounds with similar chemical structure to that of the "identified molecule," which could then be screened for their efficacy in end-use applications. This conceptual approach developed during the EAGER project is now being developed by the project team.


Last Modified: 11/12/2020
Modified by: Brent H Shanks
